tennis_resources.Title: ITF Rules of Tennis (2025)
tennis_resources.extracted_content:
# ITF Rules of Tennis - Key Points

## Scoring System
- **Game Scoring**: 0, 15, 30, 40, game
- **Set Scoring**: First to 6 games with 2-game margin, or 7-6 tiebreaker
- **Match Format**: Best of 3 or 5 sets depending on tournament level
- **Tiebreaker**: First to 7 points with 2-point margin at 6-6 in sets

## Court and Equipment Rules
- **Court Dimensions**: 78 feet long, 27 feet wide (36 feet for doubles)
- **Net Height**: 3 feet at center, 3.5 feet at posts
- **Ball Specifications**: 2.57-2.70 inches diameter, 1.975-2.095 ounces weight
- **Racquet Rules**: Maximum 29 inches length, 12.5 inches width

## Service Rules
- **Service Order**: Alternates each game
- **Service Position**: Behind baseline, between center mark and sideline
- **Let Service**: Replay if ball touches net but lands in service box
- **Foot Fault**: Foot cannot touch baseline before contact

## Code Violations
- **Time Violations**: 25 seconds between points
- **Coaching**: Not allowed during play (except designated periods)
- **Racquet Abuse**: Penalty for violent action against equipment
- **Unsportsmanlike Conduct**: Warning system for inappropriate behavior

tennis_resources.Title: USTA Sport Science: Biomechanical Analysis of the Tennis Volley
tennis_resources.extracted_content:
# Tennis Volley Biomechanics

## Technical Checkpoints

### Preparation Phase
- **Ready Position**: Racquet up, weight on balls of feet
- **Split Step Timing**: As opponent makes contact with ball
- **Early Preparation**: Racquet back as soon as ball direction is identified
- **Compact Backswing**: Minimal wind-up for quick reaction time

### Contact Phase
- **Contact Point**: In front of body, at comfortable reach
- **Firm Grip**: Tighten grip just before contact
- **Stable Wrist**: Maintain wrist position through contact
- **Forward Movement**: Move into the ball, don't let it come to you

### Follow-Through
- **Short Follow-Through**: Control over power
- **Direction Control**: Follow-through toward target
- **Recovery**: Immediately return to ready position

## Biomechanical Principles

### Force Generation
- **Kinetic Chain**: Ground reaction forces transfer through legs to upper body
- **Core Stability**: Trunk provides stable platform for arm action
- **Timing**: Synchronization of body segments for optimal power transfer

### Injury Prevention
- **Shoulder Stability**: Maintain scapular control throughout motion
- **Elbow Position**: Keep elbow in front of body to reduce stress
- **Wrist Alignment**: Neutral wrist position prevents overuse injuries
- **Proper Footwork**: Good positioning reduces compensatory movements

tennis_resources.Title: ITF Conditioning: Fitness Training
tennis_resources.extracted_content:
# Tennis-Specific Fitness Training

## Training Principles

### Periodization
- **Off-Season**: Build aerobic base and general strength
- **Pre-Season**: Develop tennis-specific fitness
- **In-Season**: Maintain fitness while managing fatigue
- **Recovery**: Active rest and injury prevention

### Energy Systems
- **Aerobic Base**: Foundation for recovery between points
- **Anaerobic Power**: Short bursts of high-intensity movement
- **Neuromuscular**: Quick reactions and explosive movements

## Fitness Components

### Cardiovascular Endurance
- **Court Sprints**: 15-30 seconds with rest periods
- **Interval Training**: Mix of high and moderate intensity
- **Cross-Training**: Running, cycling, swimming for base fitness

### Speed and Agility
- **First Step Quickness**: Explosive movement from ready position
- **Multi-Directional Movement**: Forward, backward, lateral patterns
- **Reaction Training**: Response to visual and auditory cues
- **Change of Direction**: Deceleration and acceleration skills

### Strength Training
- **Functional Movements**: Exercises that mimic tennis patterns
- **Core Stability**: Rotational strength for powerful strokes
- **Single-Leg Strength**: Improve balance and prevent injury
- **Shoulder Complex**: Prevent overuse injuries from repetitive motions

### Flexibility and Mobility
- **Dynamic Warm-Up**: Prepare joints for tennis movements
- **Static Stretching**: Post-training flexibility maintenance
- **Injury Prevention**: Target tight areas (hip flexors, shoulders)
- **Recovery**: Aid muscle repair and reduce soreness

tennis_resources.Title: Tennis Strategy Booklet
tennis_resources.extracted_content:
# Tennis Strategy and Tactics

## Singles Strategy

### Baseline Patterns
- **Cross-Court Rally**: Safest shot with highest net clearance and longest court distance
- **Inside-Out Forehand**: Running around backhand to hit forehand cross-court
- **Short Ball Attack**: Move forward and hit down-the-line or sharp angle
- **Defensive Lob**: High, deep ball to reset point when under pressure

### Serve Patterns
- **First Serve**: Target corners - wide, T, or body jam
- **Second Serve**: Focus on placement over power, use spin
- **Serve + 1**: Plan the next shot before serving
- **Return Positions**: Stand closer for second serves

### Court Positioning
- **Recovery Position**: Return to center of possible return angles
- **Offensive Position**: Move inside baseline when attacking
- **Defensive Position**: Move back to handle pace and give time

## Doubles Strategy

### Formations
- **Both Back**: Safe receiving formation
- **One Up, One Back**: Standard serving formation
- **Both Up**: Aggressive net position for finishing
- **Australian Formation**: Server and partner on same side

### Key Tactics
- **Poaching**: Net player crosses to intercept return
- **Down the Middle**: Safest passing shot in doubles
- **Lob Over Net Player**: Effective when both players are up
- **Body Shots**: Target the player between two opponents
